Chapter 4: Questions on the Methods of Establishing Boundaries, Part 4. Questions:
How does one establish boundaries?
Answer:
The method of establishing boundaries.
In uninhabited places such as mountains and fields, one can establish them as far as one wishes. In cities and villages, one cannot establish them too far away, nor can one establish them at night.
When establishing them, bhiká¹£us must stand at the four corners, and outsiders cannot be allowed to enter. If outsiders enter, the boundary will not be established.
First, establish the boundary area, and then all the monks and lay disciples are placed within the boundary area, and then the four directions are measured.
When establishing the boundary, four places are excluded:
First, a village;
Second, outside the village, a place where laypeople always work on their fields;

Third, if in a secluded place or a solitary mountain or wilderness, fearing that during the precepts or karman there may be various difficulties and one cannot come, one requests the assembly to separately establish a small boundary. If the assembly agrees, without a group of five people, one should send a monk to establish a separate boundary. This refers to a secluded place for sitting.
Fourth, the ordination platform, if the previously established boundary is uneven, exclude the establishment of the boundary platform.
This is the establishment of the boundary, and this is the matter.
Or if first the large boundary is established, and then the ordination platform is established within it for receiving the precepts, as what Master Bei said, fearing there will be nothing gained.
However, it is said that not knowing is the same as before the rule was established, relying on the general understanding.
This path may have some luck.
The person said, If there are sick monks who cannot go to the Sangha to request a separate boundary within a building, the Sangha should also allow it.
First, untie the large boundary and establish a separate boundary, establish the separate boundary, and then re-establish the large boundary.
All monks cannot enter without their robes at night.

In a dwelling place with a boundary, a single monk can also strike the gavel and extensively explain the precepts, first confessing to the Sangha in the four directions and then explaining, or it can be done in three statements.
The three statements refer to three recitations.

Chapter 5: Questions on the Summer Retreat. Question:
How many days before the summer retreat can one enter the retreat?
Answer:
From the sixteenth day of the fourth month to the fifteenth day of the fifth month, one can enter the retreat on any day. This is called the retreat.

If there are difficulties at the beginning, one cannot enter the retreat. If one enters the retreat on the fifth, fourth, third, or even the last day of the month, one does not lose the previous retreat. This is called entering the retreat on the thirtieth day and observing the retreat for one day. Those who enter the retreat later can only enter the retreat for one day.

After the fifteenth day of the seventh month, if there are difficulties, one can observe the retreat every day until the fifteenth day of the eighth month. This is called entering the retreat on one day and observing the retreat for thirty days.
Question:

When the seven days are completed, one may receive it again.
If one is worried about forgetting, one can receive it daily.

If one does not receive it at the beginning of the retreat, it is also permissible to receive it at the time of departure.

If the matter cannot be resolved, it is also permissible to spend the summer retreat at that place.
